metadata.name: Particularization #77
metadata.description:
“Particularization” is the seventh collection released as a part of NeoMent's "Abandoned Reality" series.

All concepts can be viewed from different levels. You can focus on the details, leaving out the generalized result but understanding the finer points. Or you could emphasize the concept as a whole, comprehending it well overall but missing out on the specifics. It's impossible to choose both, you have to figure out which approach works best for each scenario.

Abstract paintings made with code.

@VolatileMoods

January, 2022.

metadata.name: Glass, Ruler, Pen #191
metadata.description:
Memories of childhood, so simple, all you need is paper,
Glass, Ruler, Pen.

metadata.name: Turbulence #497
metadata.description:
Swirly shapes are rendered by passes of poisson samples of a warped noise field. The noise shifts with each pass, creating a layered effect. 

Dense editions may take over 2 minutes to draw fully.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.

Press ’s’ to save a screenshot. Image size is 928x1200px
Press ’p’ to pause/resume at any time during the drawing.

Add '&size=#' to the end of the live view URL to render a not 1:1 variation of your edition at a resolution up to 3,000 px.

Common:
- 43 set palettes plus many more with combinations
- 3 color distribution methods
- 50/50 dark
- 50/50 monochrome with bright highlights 
- 3 drawing styles: lines, points, colored pencils
- 5 noises effects: full screen, distance from center, distance from bottom, horizontal center, vertical center, random circles, 3,5, or 7 horizontal and vertical bars
- Poisson point distribution based on set layers or the noise value

Rare
- 15% chance of a dark monochrome with gold strands

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: el inefable momento #45
metadata.description:
"el inefable momento del colorido descubrimiento" ("the ineffable moment of the colorful discovery")  is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022.

It is a tribute to playful discovery. This work was commissioned for the Art Basel Hong Kong / Tezos / fxhash collaboration, as part of an activity to introduce visitors into generative art. As I was pondering what could I do in the short time available, I saw my youngest daughter drawing: the ineffable moment of colorful discovery. Child play is one of the most discovery-filled activities I can think of. And drawing is that joy that I describe: a blank piece of paper with a crayon is pure possibility. Which is what generative art is. I had wanted for quite some time to create a tribute to those drawings my daughters do, and this has been the perfect occasion to start it: it seemed to me that it fit the occasion perfectly: kids discover through painting, maybe adults can discover generative art using the same visual language.

"el inefable momento del colorido descubrimiento" is a work that explores colour and irregular basic shapes, and that leaves the viewer in front of a new space with each execution. Does it trigger any excitement to see those imperfect elements? It is dearest to me to see the hearts and rainbows, as two mainstays of the drawings that I keep in folders and count in the hundreds and thousands. Can an algorithm that reproduces those elements trigger the same warm feelings in the viewer? It does with me.

The piece lets the viewer explore certain characteristics. The viewer can pause the iterations: each is just an execution of the same drawing, slightly different. When paused, one can look at each line individually and notice how the drawing is constructed. When running, it gives an idea of how the things we know are just versions of the ideal concept they represent. 

Also, one can have an idea of what would have happened if the child had decided to draw more or less elements. The viewer can press “e” to see different variations of the same piece: random elements are selected and displayed. To restore the original work, press “r”. Which one is the “finished” artwork? All of them. What is “the” artwork? 

The work has the following commands:

- Change the work: “e”. To restore: “r”
- The painting can be paused/unpaused pressing “p”
- The viewer can save an artwork pressing “s” (it will pause the piece, press "p" to unpause)
- The resolution can be arbitrarily changed pressing “d” followed by a number from 1 to 9. If the image goes dark and nothing paints, press “d 0” (d zero) and try again with a lower number. Resolution can be increased iteratively: press d 2, then d 2, etc. It will always add the amount to the current pixel density, thus increasing resolution.
- The viewer can see how many decisions are made per iteration. This might be interesting to those who don’t know how generative art works. Each iteration is composed of thousands of decisions that inform colour, positions, shapes, etc. To toggle the decision count view, press “q”
- It has also colour controls: press z for brightness, x for contrast, g for gamma, b for blur, n for noise followed by + or - to alter their values. You might get some simple variations that you might enjoy. Press a to enable/disable all colour controls (except the noise).
- There are some pre-recorded colour variations: press “v” followed by 1, 2 or 3. Press “v” followed by 0 (zero) to reset the variations.

In every process of discovery, one comes to an "aha" moment ;) If you find your aha moment, then you can do one more thing: you can play with the size of certain elements pressing “o”. To restore, reload the piece. Once you find your aha moment, you can go back the same way you got there. All the controls work the same when one has reached their aha moment.

I hope you enjoy the piece as much as I have enjoyed drawing it, directly or indirectly, with my daughters. Thanks.

Artwork by Marcelo Soria-Rodríguez, @msoriaro.
Made with p5js and glsl.

created with p5js | on Earth 2022

metadata.name: The beauty of imperfection #97
metadata.description:
Drawing shapes repeatedly, spinning and rotating. I use basic shapes like square, rectangle, and triangle to create this art. Regular shapes are perfect but it's a little bit boring, so I make them imperfect, just like "hand drawing". I also tried to make this generative art great for physical print, so that I can hang it on the wall. Here we go.

5 background colors:
Black, White, Blue, Green, and Red

Press “space” to play animation.
Press “s” to save.

Made with p5js.
Created by Costa C. | OneRocket.nft

metadata.name: Ambiguous Instances #42
metadata.description:
“Ambiguous Instances” is the sixth collection released as a part of NeoMent's "Abandoned Reality" series.

Often people use a specific example to argue their point of view. Unfortunately, this means that they can completely make it up or hyperbolise it to benefit their views, which means that it's a completely invalid argument.

Statistics, on the other hand, cannot lie, since they are just pure observations.
That is unless they are completely made up, of course.

metadata.name: Negative Space #104
metadata.description:
In this piece, special attention is paid to negative space, which is emphasized by simple / bold color palettes.

6 different styles
- Network
- Parachutes
- Flow
- Limbs
- Arcs
- Florals

9 different color palettes
- dark
- light
- yellow
- blue
- red
- green
- blue and yellow
- red and blue
- multi

Press any key to download a hi-res png.

p5.js script with a custom shader. Depending on the settings, it take some time to fully render / draw.

metadata.name: Paper Planes #179
metadata.description:
The joys of childhood are too easily forgotten. Paper Planes is a generative art collection celebrating the joy and magic of origami: from the simplest materials spring delightful forms brimming with ingenuity.

In homage to the handicraft of paper folding, we developed a collection of four pens each with a unique hand-drawn feel: Ink, Pencil, Gel and Dip. They ensure each of our ten origami birds are sketched with subtle imperfections.

Many of the birds are folded from patterned paper based on three traditional Japanese patterns: Seigaiha, Kōjitsunagi and Shippō. Other birds are crafted from block coloured paper which provides pop and contrast whilst sometimes birds match their background, accentuating the hand-drawn strokes that sketched them.

A range of layouts bring each mint to life. Birds can flock and fly across the page. They can be confined to a regimented grid or they can escape and embrace the chaos of the currents. Contrasting frames and borders highlight different colours within each of the 15 handcrafted palettes.

If you're feeling mischievous you can press 'C' in live view to ruffle some feathers…

https://www.phaust.art/paper-planes

----------

In live view, press 'S' to save a high resolution download or add '&size=#' to the end of the URL to render at a custom height.

Original artwork by Phaust. Spring 2022. London / Brighton. Made with p5js.

attributes.name: Birds
attributes.value: Chaffinch, Chonk, Crane, Dove, Grouse, Hummingbird, Lapwing, Parakeet, Redshank and Warbler

metadata.name: Seasons #222
metadata.description:
Seasons depicts monolithic mountains and calm seas scattered with unnatural elements.
The color palettes explore the colors of natural landscapes through different times of year.

To ease browser load, the images are paused by default.
Hitting 'p' will toggle a subtle animation.
Hitting 't' will toggle between the day and night palette for the image.
On mobile the resolution is reduced and the image is always paused to ease the load on the device.

Generative images by 0x3739
twitter.com/0x3739
library: twgljs - A Tiny WebGL helper Library
license: CC-BY-NC-SA 4.0
Tested and functioning correctly on Google Chrome version 100.0.4896.88 on Windows desktop and Android mobile device.

The work is rendered in webgl as a fragment shader.
Setting parameters in the javascript portion of the script generates a different fragment shader for each iteration.

Interactions
'-' to zoom in.
'+' to zoom out.
'f' to change the aspect ratio to fullscreen.
'z' to change the aspect ratio to square.
'a' to change the aspect ratio to A4/A3/A2/A1 format.
'w' to change the aspect ratio to 16:9.
'q' to change the aspect ratio to portrait.
's' to save an image of the canvas.
'p' to pause the animation the image.
't' to toggle the time (day/night) in the image.
'b' to toggle the margins on the image.
'm' to toggle the mountains in the image.
'c' to toggle the clouds in the image.
'g' to toggle the grid in the image.
'd' to toggle the dirt speckles in the image.
'n' to toggle the noise in the image.
'j' to toggle the jitter in the image.
'v' to toggle all vintage effects in the image.
'1' to toggle the stars in the image.
'2' to toggle the moons in the image.
'3' to toggle the black squares in the image.
'4' to toggle the white squares in the image.
'5' to toggle the primary color squares in the image.
'6' to toggle the secundary color squares in the image.
'7' to toggle the colour correction in the image.
'8' to toggle the sea in the image.
'h' to increase the quality modifier (maximum is 3).
'l' to decrease the quality modifier (minimum is 1).
The quality modifier is a modifier on the width and height of the canvas.
Changing the modifier can affect the look of the image due to subpixel artifacts.
The modifier can be used to save higher resolution images.
Higher values of the modifier increase memory usage and can cause a browser or webgl instance to crash. 
'arrow_up' to move up in the image.
'arrow_down' to move down in the image.
'arrow_right' to move right in the image.
'arrow_left' to move left in the image.

metadata.name: Bedlam #150
metadata.description:
Originally a study of paint brushes and texture, this project morphed. I started to find a medley of painting with the texture of handmade rugs, leveraging this medium to not just recreate the everyday, but let my imagination run. 

Enjoy each abstract piece that "Bedlam" has to offer, with 25 palettes, 5 brush styles, and an endless combination of stroke lengths and layering effects, there is much to be discovered.

It can take up to a minute for the Painting to finish, depending on your hardware.

Press 's' in Live View to save a png.

metadata.name: Far horizons #13
metadata.description:
Peaceful, peaceful and beautiful sunsets and sunrises on distant shores and even if you imagine on unknown planets in the depths of space.

Keys
's' to save current frame
